title: Sources
text:
The data in this project was extracted from the US Census Bureau. The data are downloaded in a CSV to make the data easier to read as a human, although this CSV file is never actually used in the code, instead, an API key was used to extract the necessary data directly from the US Census Bureau database.
The data are then trimmed down to only the necessary variables which can be used to create the plot. the tidycensus and tidyverse libraries were used in this project. No observations were explicitly removed, however those that were not being looked at were not used.

title: About
text:
I am Nicholas Oliver Silveira Powell, An American who often speaks Spanish at home. I can be contacted at nicholasospowell@gmail.com and my github is https://github.com/nickospowell
This project was made in order to look at education rates of those who speak different languages all around the US. It can be found at https://github.com/nickospowell/language-education
This project was created as a part of Kaneâ€™s Data Science Bootcamp. https://bootcamp.davidkane.info/

title: Language Education Data
text: 21.6% of Americans speak a language other than English at home. The following data was pulled from the US Census Bureau. The relevant variables were pulled to analyse the relationship between language spoken at home and education rate. While Spanish speakers seem to be at a disadvantage when it comes to education, speakers of other languages are doing almost as well as English speakers.

title: Nativity
text:
library(tidycensus)
library(tidyverse)


# Find and display correct variables from the S1603 table
variables <- load_variables(2022, "acs5", cache = TRUE) %>%
  filter(str_detect(name, "S1603"))

# Define the correct variables based on the output of load_variables
variables <- c(
  english_total = "S1603_C02_001E",   
  spanish_total = "S1603_C06_001E",   
  other_total = "S1603_C04_001E",     
  english_natives = "S1603_C02_005E" ,
  spanish_natives = "S1603_C06_005E" , 
  other_natives = "S1603_C04_005E", 
  english_naturalized = "S1603_C02_007E" ,
  spanish_naturalized = "S1603_C06_007E" , 
  other_naturalized = "S1603_C04_007E", 
  english_non_citizens = "S1603_C02_008E" ,
  spanish_non_citizens = "S1603_C06_008E" , 
  other_non_citizens = "S1603_C04_008E"
 
)

# Fetch data for the entire US
data <- get_acs(
  geography = "us",
  variables = variables,
  year = 2022,
  survey = "acs5",
  output = "wide"
)



# Calculate percentage of population with bachelor's degree
data <- data %>%
  mutate(
    english_percentage_natives = ((english_natives) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_natives = ((spanish_natives) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_natives = ((other_natives) / other_total) * 100,
    english_percentage_naturalized = ((english_naturalized) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_naturalized = ((spanish_naturalized) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_naturalized = ((other_naturalized) / other_total) * 100,
    english_percentage_non_citizens = ((english_non_citizens) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_non_citizens = ((spanish_non_citizens) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_non_citizens = ((other_non_citizens) / other_total) * 100
  )

# Reshape data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  select(english_percentage_natives, spanish_percentage_natives, other_percentage_natives, 
         english_percentage_naturalized, spanish_percentage_naturalized, other_percentage_naturalized, 
         english_percentage_non_citizens, spanish_percentage_non_citizens, other_percentage_non_citizens) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = everything(), 
    names_to = c("language", "nativity_level"), 
    names_pattern = "(.*)_(percentage_.*)",
    values_to = "percentage"
  ) %>%
  mutate(language = case_when(
    language == "english" ~ "English",
    language == "spanish" ~ "Spanish",
    language == "other" ~ "Other"
  ))
mean_data <- data_long %>%
  group_by(nativity_level, language) %>%
  summarise(mean_percentage = mean(percentage, na.rm = TRUE))


ggplot(mean_data, aes(x = nativity_level, y = mean_percentage, fill = language)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(title = "Mean Percentage by Nativity and Language",
       subtitle = "English is consistently in the lead and Spanish is consistently last",
       x = "Nativity",
       y = "Mean Percentage",
       fill = "Language", 
       caption = "Source: US Census Bureau") +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c(
    "percentage_natives" = "Native Born",
    "percentage_naturalized" = "Naturalized",
    "percentage_non_citizens" = "Non Citiznes")) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Nativity
text:
library(tidycensus)
library(tidyverse)


# Find and display correct variables from the S1603 table
variables <- load_variables(2022, "acs5", cache = TRUE) %>%
  filter(str_detect(name, "S1603"))

# Define the correct variables based on the output of load_variables
variables <- c(
  english_total = "S1603_C02_001E",   
  spanish_total = "S1603_C06_001E",   
  other_total = "S1603_C04_001E",     
  english_natives = "S1603_C02_005E" ,
  spanish_natives = "S1603_C06_005E" , 
  other_natives = "S1603_C04_005E", 
  english_naturalized = "S1603_C02_007E" ,
  spanish_naturalized = "S1603_C06_007E" , 
  other_naturalized = "S1603_C04_007E", 
  english_non_citizens = "S1603_C02_008E" ,
  spanish_non_citizens = "S1603_C06_008E" , 
  other_non_citizens = "S1603_C04_008E"
 
)

# Fetch data for the entire US
data <- get_acs(
  geography = "us",
  variables = variables,
  year = 2022,
  survey = "acs5",
  output = "wide"
)



# Calculate percentage of population with bachelor's degree
data <- data %>%
  mutate(
    english_percentage_natives = ((english_natives) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_natives = ((spanish_natives) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_natives = ((other_natives) / other_total) * 100,
    english_percentage_naturalized = ((english_naturalized) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_naturalized = ((spanish_naturalized) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_naturalized = ((other_naturalized) / other_total) * 100,
    english_percentage_non_citizens = ((english_non_citizens) / english_total) * 100,
    spanish_percentage_non_citizens = ((spanish_non_citizens) / spanish_total) * 100,
    other_percentage_non_citizens = ((other_non_citizens) / other_total) * 100
  )

# Reshape data for plotting
data_long <- data %>%
  select(english_percentage_natives, spanish_percentage_natives, other_percentage_natives, 
         english_percentage_naturalized, spanish_percentage_naturalized, other_percentage_naturalized, 
         english_percentage_non_citizens, spanish_percentage_non_citizens, other_percentage_non_citizens) %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = everything(), 
    names_to = c("language", "nativity_level"), 
    names_pattern = "(.*)_(percentage_.*)",
    values_to = "percentage"
  ) %>%
  mutate(language = case_when(
    language == "english" ~ "English",
    language == "spanish" ~ "Spanish",
    language == "other" ~ "Other"
  ))
mean_data <- data_long %>%
  group_by(nativity_level, language) %>%
  summarise(mean_percentage = mean(percentage, na.rm = TRUE))


ggplot(mean_data, aes(x = nativity_level, y = mean_percentage, fill = language)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  labs(title = "Mean Percentage by Nativity and Language",
       subtitle = "English is consistently in the lead and Spanish is consistently last",
       x = "Nativity",
       y = "Mean Percentage",
       fill = "Language", 
       caption = "Source: US Census Bureau") +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c(
    "percentage_natives" = "Native Born",
    "percentage_naturalized" = "Naturalized",
    "percentage_non_citizens" = "Non Citiznes")) +
  theme_minimal()

title: Current Split Graphs
text:
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'education_level'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.
